chapter.title: &ceph; &ogw;
chapter.para: &ceph; &ogw; is an object storage interface built on top of librgw to provide applications with a RESTful gateway to &ceph; clusters. It supports two interfaces:

listitem.para: S3-compatible: Provides object storage functionality with an interface that is compatible with a large subset of the Amazon S3 RESTful API.
Swift-compatible: Provides object storage functionality with an interface that is compatible with a large subset of the &ostack; Swift API.

chapter.para: The &ogw; daemon uses 'Beast' HTTP front-end by default. It uses the Boost.Beast library for HTTP parsing and the Boost.Asio library for asynchronous network I/O operations.

Because &ogw; provides interfaces compatible with &ostack; Swift and Amazon S3, the &ogw; has its own user management. &ogw; can store data in the same cluster that is used to store data from &cephfs; clients or &rbd; clients. The S3 and Swift APIs share a common name space, so you may write data with one API and retrieve it with the other.

sect3.title: Basic Configuration

sect3.para: Each instance must have a user name and key to communicate with a &ceph; storage cluster. In the following steps, we use a monitor node to create a bootstrap keyring, then create the &ogw; instance user keyring based on the bootstrap one. Then, we create a client user name and key. Next, we add the key to the &ceph; Storage Cluster. Finally, we distribute the keyring to the node containing the gateway instance.

tip.title: Use Bootstrap Keyring
tip.para: An alternative way is to create the &ogw; bootstrap keyring, and then create the &ogw; keyring from it:

step.para: Create an &ogw; bootstrap keyring on one of the monitor nodes:
step.screen: &prompt.root;ceph \ auth get-or-create client.bootstrap-rgw mon 'allow profile bootstrap-rgw' \ --connect-timeout=25 \ --cluster=ceph \ --name mon. \ --keyring=/var/lib/ceph/mon/ceph-NODE_HOST/keyring \ -o /var/lib/ceph/bootstrap-rgw/keyring

step.para: Create the /var/lib/ceph/radosgw/ceph-RGW_NAME directory for storing the bootstrap keyring:
Create an &ogw; keyring from the newly created bootstrap keyring:
step.screen: &prompt.root;ceph \ auth get-or-create client.rgw.RGW_NAME osd 'allow rwx' mon 'allow rw' \ --connect-timeout=25 \ --cluster=ceph \ --name client.bootstrap-rgw \ --keyring=/var/lib/ceph/bootstrap-rgw/keyring \ -o /var/lib/ceph/radosgw/ceph-RGW_NAME/keyring

sect3.title: Create Pools (Optional)
sect3.para: &ceph; &ogw;s require &ceph; Storage Cluster pools to store specific gateway data. If the user you created has proper permissions, the gateway will create the pools automatically. However, ensure that you have set an appropriate default number of placement groups per pool in the &ceph; configuration file.

important.title: &ogw; and Erasure-coded Pools
important.para: Only the default.rgw.buckets.data pool can be erasure-coded. All other pools need to be replicated, otherwise the gateway is not accessible.
